This might be challenging though; not sure how easy it is to generate polygons that are non self-intersecting and non-degenerate.

Hi @Edjy, could you kindly explain some of the math terminology here?

- Is the only definition for a supporting segment that it connects two vertices of the polygon? I don't quite understand why DE and EF and not supporting segments in your example.

- What does vertical projection mean here? Do you mean that the orthogonal projection of the centroid onto the (infinite) line containing the line segment must lie within the line segment itself?

- What does it mean for a polygon to "stand" on a segment?

Okay, so the main point here is that a supporting segment is not always an edge of the polygon, and an edge is not always a supporting segment. If you look at the puzzle image, it's maybe easier to understand:
In the example, DF is a supporting segment, as the polygon can be rotated and rest on the ground, with only D and F touching the ground. DE and EF are not supporting segments, because the polygon cannot rest on these edges (a part of it would intersect the ground). I'm not sure how to explain it in the statement.
As you said, the vertical projection is "the orthogonal projection onto the line containing the line segment". I called it vertical because in that case, the segment should rest on the ground, so the projection is orthogonal to the ground.
The polygon can "stand" on a segment when it stays in that position, and does not fall on one side. If ABCDEF is put on its FA edge (with C and D on the right), it will fall to the right, until D touches the ground, because the centroid projection on (FA) is not in the [FA] segment.
Thanks, I editited my contribution accordingly

Here's an imgur image I created to better illustrate your example polygon: https://imgur.com/a/polygon-equilibrum-rTS5hvl

I took a while to understand "standing" of the polygon as allowing the 2D polygon to interact and come to rest on a horizontal "ground". Let me ask ChatGPT for suggestions on how to make that clearer in the problem statement.

From ChatGPT:

"We consider a planar polygon with uniform density, placed on a horizontal ground line. The polygon can be rotated freely and then lowered until it touches the ground.

When the polygon is resting on the ground, it may touch the ground at one or more of its vertices. A <<supporting segment>> is defined as a pair of vertices of the polygon such that:
â€¢ Both vertices lie on the ground at the same time, and
â€¢ No other part of the polygon goes below the ground in that position.
In other words, the polygon can be positioned so that exactly those two vertices touch the ground, while the rest of the polygon lies entirely above it.

A <<stable equilibrium>> occurs when, in addition to being a supporting segment, the polygon remains at rest on that segment without tipping to either side. This happens when the center of mass of the polygon lies horizontally between the two vertices touching the ground.

Your task is to:
â€¢ Count how many distinct pairs of vertices form supporting segments.
â€¢ Count how many of these supporting segments correspond to stable equilibria."

You can probably add in the example image imgur link as reference at the end of the problem description.

Although I'm not a great fan of ChatGPT, this adds a lot of useful precisions. One detail: when resting on a supporting segment, "the polygon can be positioned so that exactly those two vertices touch the ground, while the rest of the polygon lies entirely above it" -> there can be more than two vertices, if several vertices are aligned (a reversed W for example). I'll try to rework the whole statement with the help of your explanations and the image.
Static vs stable: If I understand correctly, in the statement example, all equilibriums are static, because they can't be moved. They can be unstable, if the projection of the centroid lies exactly on one end of the supporting segment (but I did not tackle this problem in the puzzle).

Feel free to rework the ChatGPT-generated statement! I did also notice the issue of when k>2 polygon vertices touch the ground at the same time, forming kC2 possible supporting segments. If this was not part of your test cases, you could consider including a separate statement in the constraints section.

As for the statement example, the polygon resting on the supporting segment FA seems to be in static equilibrium (since the polygon does not move, as you point out) but is not in stable equilibrium (as gravity will cause the polygon to fall should movement be allowed). Since we discount FA from the number of equilibria, I took it to mean that we are looking for stable equilibria. Do let me know if I'm misunderstanding the statement!

Several tests and validators already feature segments with more than 2 vertices: "multiple vertices supporting segment", "weird shape" and "CG/ADA". In these cases, the supporting segment goes from the leftmost vertex to the rightmost vertex on the ground. To me, it feels quite obvious, as when you imagine the polygon being rotated, only one of these 2 points can be the pivot on the ground, but do you think I should clarify this as well?

The polygon resting on FA is not in a static equilibrium. As per Wikipedia, it would be in static equilibrium if the net force was zero, which it is not: the forces that apply (gravity and ground normal reaction) will cause it to "fall" on the right side, or more precisely rotate around F. But I don't think the difference between static and stable matters a lot in this puzzle.
The static vs stable distinction does matter because they're different concepts, which require different solutions.

From what I understood:
- static: nothing will make it move (sum of the forces is zero)
- stable: it will come back to the same position after small perturbations
In this case (a polygon resting on the ground), all static equilibriums are included in the stable equilibriums. The only difference is, as stated previously, if the projection of the centroid on the segment lies exactly on one of its end points, where the equilibrium might be unstable, even if static. Example: (1, 0), (2, 0), (1, 1), (0, 1). But I did not include any testcase with unstable equilibriums. All equilibriums are both static and stable.
That's why I chose to write "static", and don't think that "stable" would make the solutions any different.
Can you explain more what is a supporting segment and what is a static equilibrum? I donâ€™t now what it is, and I donâ€™t understand the problem.
And one more thing, you donâ€™t put the space between "where" and "as" in the goal.

User123's image shows supporting segments in red, along the ground: https://imgur.com/a/polygon-equilibrum-9Ubqp0b
In fact, they are the edges of the convex hull.
The equilibrium that we are discussing is the situation where the polygon can stand by its own on a supporting segment (states 1-4 on the same image). If not in equilibrium, the polygon will "roll" on one side until resting at equilibrium on another supporting segment.
